Hospitalization Record.Chief Complaint: Crying, limited mouth opening, difficulty sucking for 8 hours

Present Illness.Onset: Symptoms noted immediately after birth in the delivery room.
Present Illness.Main Symptoms: Crying, limited mouth opening, difficulty sucking which have been persistent since onset.
Present Illness.General Condition Changes: Appears irritable, difficulties with feeding, reduced sleep, normal urination and defecation, no weight change evident yet.

Marital and Family History.Family History: Parents healthy, no similar diseases reported in family history.

Systematic Examination.Head and Organs: Head normal, no sign of trauma, fontanelles soft and flat
Systematic Examination.Chest: Clear lungs bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles, heart sounds regular, no murmurs

Hospitalization Record.Specialist Examination: Suspected neonatal tetanus based on symptoms and hypertonicity.
Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination: CBC normal, CRP slightly elevated. Blood cultures pending. CSF examination pending.
Hospitalization Record.Diagnostic Basis: Based on history of perinatal period, physical exam showing hypertonicity, difficulty feeding, limited mouth opening, and crying.
Hospitalization Record.Differential Diagnosis: Purulent meningitis (ruled out by current lack of fever or neck stiffness), neonatal convulsions (no seizure activity observed), tetany (less likely due to normal calcium levels).

Post-Admission Course Records.First Course Record: 8 hours old male with symptoms of crying, limited mouth opening, and difficulty sucking. Suspected neonatal tetanus. Blood work initiated, monitoring for signs of progression. Started on empirical antibiotic therapy pending confirmation of diagnosis.
Post-Admission Course Records.Daily Course Records: Day 1: Continues to show hypertonicity and difficulty feeding. Remains stable, no seizure activity, continued monitoring and supportive care.
Post-Admission Course Records.Senior Physician Rounds Records: Reviewed by senior pediatrician: Agreed with suspected diagnosis of neonatal tetanus, continued empirical antibiotics and supportive measures. Advised close monitoring.
Post-Admission Course Records.Handover Records: Shift handover: Monitored patient stability, emphasis on respiratory status and feeding difficulties.
Post-Admission Course Records.Stage Summary: 8-hour old male presenting with symptoms consistent with neonatal tetanus, stable after initial management, supportive and empirical antibiotic therapy ongoing.

Medical Orders.Long-term Orders: Monitor vital signs every 2 hours. Continue empirical antibiotic therapy. Provide IV fluids and nutrition support.
Medical Orders.Temporary Orders: Draw blood cultures and CBC. Prepare for lumbar puncture if signs of meningeal involvement appear. Administer tetanus immunoglobulin if necessary.

Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination Reports: Pending CSF results and blood culture.
Hospitalization Record.Temperature Chart: Temp: 36.8°C, Pulse: 140 bpm, Resp: 45 breaths/min, BP: Not measured.
Hospitalization Record.Special Examination Consent: Consent obtained for all required investigations.
Hospitalization Record.Critical Condition Notice: Parents informed about the critical nature of the condition and the need for close monitoring.

qa_summary.answer: Y. Mendoza's symptoms started immediately after birth in the delivery room. He has been crying, has limited mouth opening, and difficulty sucking since onset.
